comment._content: By the time I saw it it was also a bit scruffier round the front, having been rebuilt in 1970. Badly.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The station could not stay stationary -
" The original Portadown station was sited half a mile east of the present station and opened on 12 September 1842, replacing a temporary station at Seagoe that had opened the preceding year. The Portadown station was moved to the present location in 1848 then reverted to its original site between 1863 and 1970. Goods traffic ceased on 4 January 1965. The present station opened in 1970, replacing a large and largely redundant station. ... "
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portadown_railway_station Clear as mud !

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Are you sure about the dates? It looks like the station marked on the 1857 OS map rather than the Old Station, but by 1879 the station had moved back to the old station site.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The railway station is on the 1947 edition of the 10inch OS Map maps.osni.gov.uk/MapConsoleHistoricalMaps.aspx at the end of Watson's Street. The current view is a sorry sight! All that remains are the gate pillars painted in a lovely red, white and blue colour with what looks like the makings or remains of a bonfire in the driveway maps.google.ie/maps?q=Portadown+Railway+Station&ll=54...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: www.geograph.ie/photo/2347044 3rd railway station, doesn't tell you much since we don't know if the Seagoe station is counted. However, it say's it was demolished and replaced with the lurgan road, which I think puts it on the site of the original non-temporary station, so the date of 1879 is grand.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Sorry sight, indeed! That's a bit depressing, but thank you for the maps link - now added to our Flickr Map...

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] On 15 January 1950 the Ulster Transport Authority (UTA) withdrew services on the former Belfast & County Down Railway (BCDR) lines between Comber and Newcastle; Ballynahinch Junction and Ballynahinch; and Downpatrick and Ardglass.  At the time of the dissolution of the Great Northern Railway (GNRI) Board in 1957-1958, the Northern Ireland Government closed all GNRI lines in NI except the Belfast-Dundalk and Portadown-Derry main lines and the Newry-Warrenpoint and Lisburn–Antrim branches.  Portadown-Derry and Newry-Warrenpoint subsequently closed following the Benson Report in 1965.
Beeching did not publish his reports on the restructuring of railways in Great Britain until 1963 and 1965.

comment.author: 30622421@N03

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The number of platforms and large number of daily trains mentioned in that article are in contrast to how quiet it seems in the image above!

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] I was under the assumption that Ulster would have come under the British Railways Board of the time. I stand corrected!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56105315@N07] The Ulster Transport Authority was controlled by the N.I. Government at Stormont who left it to its' own devices to make the most monumental cock ups and financial disasters which would eventually lead to the breakup of the organisation with the operating subsidiaries running separately. The railways then faired the worst with massive under investment and the results of some fundamentally bad business decisions.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] They were closed to make savings and had been uneconomic in their then format. At the time though there were no motorways in N.I. and the working population was generally less mobile than it is today. The Comber line should never have shut as it would now be a major revenue earner and a key suburban line into Belfast. You only have to look at how the network has switched from rail to bus and look at the business levels to see what should have happened. The UTA/N.I. Railways basically faffed around for years without any investment. The fact that they couldn't even make their minds up as to how to run a service from Belfast to Derry/Londonderry speaks volumes. They kept changing termini in Belfast and changing routes to suit themselves rather than their customers.

The fact was that buses were cheaper to operate and adapt so they took over the market.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] We still have only a train every two hours off peak on the Derry line.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] What about the Goldline services that Ulsterbus run though?

It even took Ulsterbus quite a while to realise that people wanting to go to Derry from Belfast or vice versa didn't want to go via Dungannon-Ballygawley-Omagh-Strabane-Victoria Bridge but wanted instead to go straight over the Glenshane Pass - which is why you now have the services by coach principally rather than rail! 

The major opportunity missed even now is rail freight! Look at how Stobarts now trans ship stuff for Tescos by rail and then distribute by road on the mainland! UTA had the network before the trucks came. Even in my day the Ulsterbus Parcels network could run rings round any distribution company for speed! They should be making more use of the Belfast-Dublin and Belfast-Derry lines but don't!

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: Goldline services are grand. I use them whenever the train does not deliver but I have to go to the Europa Bus Centre. That means getting either a train or bus into Belfast first.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] As to your claim that "Post no Bills" is discriminatory I think that you are suffering from a bad dose of political correctness gone wrong.  I have several times seen cases where Bills were posted indiscriminately and when other posters attempted to post letters and small parcels there was no longer any room left in the postbox!  I have also seen where Bills were not posted properly and the boot, socks and even full legs were left hanging out of the slot on the box, most unsightly and unbecoming, especially if the socks needed darning.  Think carefully before you cry wolf in future I say!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
Whilst we are talking about posting, I heard Simon Mayo interview a chap about last posting dates for Christmas etc on BBC Radio 2. Mr Mayo was clearly expecting to speak to someone from the Royal Mail/Post Office but the person who appeared at the end of the line turned out to be the Vice President of Sales for the UK of DHL(!). So clearly embarrassed that Mr DHL could not actually speak on behalf of the Royal Mail, Mr Mayo embarked on an interview about what was the biggest thing they had shipped etc and what could be drawn from the conversation was:
1. Mr DHL had lived in Dubai at some point (he was English) and had shipped a Xmas tree from USA(!) to Dubai and it was so big he had to cut 4 feet off the bottom to get it to fit into his lounge
2. Due to customs requirements, you cannot :
(a) Ship wheel barrows to Nigeria - although no one could explain why (perhaps the Royal family there have acquired enough via email scams)
(b) Ship shoes in pairs to Spain - you can ship "odd pairs" (ie two different shoes but not the same ones)

So there you have it today's useless facts "Posted by Bill"!

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: It was a wonderful looking building back in the day, shocking it was bulldozed and replaced by this nondescript structure nearby! Sadly this was one of a number of large Victorian stations to be abandoned during the early years of NIR, others include Ballymena and Larne. The Lawrence photograph depicts Portadown when it still had an overall roof covering the platforms, this was later removed in 1920 and replaced by ordinary platform canopies. The old Monaghan station, of similar design, is the only one still standing.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Monaghan station is from 1860, and also possibly designed by John MacNeill "on a more modest scale than his masterwork at Portadown "according to Archiseek.

comment.author: 89520978@N08
comment._content: Nick Stewart's comment that he thought it was a country estate before he read the narrative got me. It was what I and no doubt many others of us did . I had in the flash of insight of a country estate created a marvellous story regarding the humble role of the soul delivering whatever he is to the grand folks and why was the front gate being made so messy by a vandal or was it an announcement of the coming charitable fair on the neighbouring green courtesy of the grand folks. I wonder about the architecture of some of these railway station buildings everywhere being reminiscent of a stately home. I wonder who the architect/administrator was who began this fashion.
